commitResults.messageTitle: Completed Level-0. Renamed the chatbot to Mortal Reminder.
Updated the README to remove template information and replace it with my own placeholders.
Updated Level-0. Changed all non-main methods from static to non-static types.
Renamed ToDoList.java to Storage.java in occurrences and files.
Added a new line at the end of Task.java file.

commitResults.messageBody:
The list inside storage only stores Strings which are primitive structures.

Primitive Structures does not allow for complex representation of data which is what we eventually want to achieve with the Todos, Events and Deadlines in this project.

Thus, the list structure in the storage class needs to be modified and the accompanying methods also need to be fixed accordingly to allow a more complex data structure,  the Task class, to be stored in the list.

This allows each item inside the list to be packaged with both the task name and the mark status together in one object, and eventually we can extend this to other information we want to store together instead of separately.

The name storage should be reserved for dealing with loading and saving tasks in the file.

The current structure inside the file TaskList.java contains the task list itself and has operations to add/delete tasks in the list.

I will eventually separate the two but since this file already contains the tasklist itself, i will proceed to keep rename it as TaskList.java.

This will prevent further confusion in future and is more intuitive for the reader of this code to follow.

Regression testing manually is time consuming and laborious. This problem will only become more difficult to solve as the codebase increases in size.

I automated test scripts, expected input, expected output txt files were modified with relevant regression testing cases. I also updated the .sh file with the new name of the main file to allow the testing.

This will automate the testing process and save time.

I forsee the use of AI to autocomplete quite alot of methods which are similar to each other.

Many of the methods which I forsee creating are kind of repetitive and time consuming in the next few levels.

As such I have created AI.md to explain my rationale for using AI tools in a widespread manner and the explanations behind each use.

This will allow me to document my AI tools used concurrently with the progress of the project, to ensure adherence to the rules of the use of AI in the project.

There is many different parts of the code dealing with making sense of the user input.

This makes the debugging process and the code itself very messy.

In order to modulate the code better, I have created Parser.java to only handle all of the user input and change it to a state that the program can understand.

This will allow centralised handling of user inputs and better management of commands by the program.

I noticed the commands starting to become more and more complex.

More complex commands need to be represented by their own classes
to ensure the data is well modulated and communicated within the program
more efficiently.

Lets create a class to package command information together for easier storage
and communication and another class CommandExecutor to help execute such
commands instead of doing everything within the Parser class.

This ensures a cleaner code base, with all information referring to
commands and their executions within these files while the parser only handles
parsing user input. This will help with easier debugging due to better modularity.

I noticed the commands starting to become more and more complex.

More complex commands need to be represented by their own classes
to ensure the data is well modulated and communicated within the program
more efficiently.

Lets create a class to package command information together for easier storage
and communication and another class CommandExecutor to help execute such
commands instead of doing everything within the Parser class.

This ensures a cleaner code base, with all information referring to
commands and their executions within these files while the parser only handles
parsing user input. This will help with easier debugging due to better modularity.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/Command.java
#	src/main/java/CommandExecutor.java

There is too many printing instances in many different files.

The formatting of the output is not always consistent and the handling of the printing is very messy for the coder.

Lets create a new printing class to handle all of the outputs from the chatbot. Ensure that the class is static so
that new instances will not have to be called and the printing can be done by invoking the class name only.

Using a static class to handle all the printing ensures that there is only one operation of printing
and multiple instances of printing does not occur within the program, leading to messy outputs.
It also makes it easier to use the printer anywhere without having to instantiate it leading to
cleaner code and debugging.

commitResults.messageTitle: Updated all files with new Format Print.
commitResults.messageBody:
All these files had some printing involved and were inconsistent in formatting.

Lets modify them to ensure consistent output generated by the chatbot by incorporating
the FormattedPrinting class.

The Task class has the common behaviour for all the different types
of items that can be found inside of the TaskList inside the chatbot.

However, it cannot capture all possible types of behaviours of the
many different types of tasks such as ToDos, Deadlines and Events
which all need to be configured differently.

Let's use polymorphism to extend the task class to these 3 different
classes. Let's change Task class to an abstract class with an abstract
method "getDesctiption" which is to be implemented differently by
each different type of Task. The constructor will also be shortened
to allow each type of Task to store the description differently.
Lastly, lets change the CommandExecutor file to call these different
types of tasks under each different types of commands.

Using polymorphism allows for the 3 different classes to have common
behaviours that do not need to be recoded at any minor change while
also be called using a common object type (Task) especially when we
are not sure what type of object will be returned. This also gives
us flexibility to change the behaviour of each class independently
from one another.

Changed the Constructor to include the description during
initialisation.

Long switch statement inside of Parser.java is not ideal.

It needs to be manually modified every time a new comment is added.
This means we are repeating the change every time we were to add a
new command both to the Enum List inside the CommandExecutor file
and the Parser file.

Lets create a separate Enum file to abstract out all the possible
commands and create a method inside Parser.java to search for the
command inside this Enum class.

Using enum's is preferable than a bunch of switch statements as it
reduces the amount of recoding necessary when new commands are
implemented and it also makes the code look cleaner to readers.

The program is not built to handle errors correctly.

This causes the program to crash if there is an input error by the
user, thus the program is not able to provide feedback to the user
about their input.

Let's add the following error handling functionality to the chatbot:
- marking/unmarking error: when the user tries to mark something
  that has already been marked/unmarked
- trying to view or mark items in an empty list
- adding a task without anything
- adding incorrect number of inputs for todo, deadline and events
  respectively.
- entering non-integers after mark/unmark
- marking/unmarking items out of the bounds of the list.

With the following error handling, the chatbot becomes more robust
and is able to provide useful feedback to the user about their input
so that the user is able to self correct their mistakes.

There is no way to delete tasks after you are done with them.

This makes the list look very messy after a few tasks have been
completed.

Let's create a delete functionality to allow users to delete tasks.

This will make the list easier to organise for the user, especially
if they have completed a task or added the task wrongly.

The amount of things to test per new function added is increasing.

This makes regression testing very laborious and time consuming.

Lets set-up semi automated testing using expected and input text
files to speed up the testing process.

This will make future testing quicker and less labour intensive.

Reformatted code to follow the code style required for CS2103 module
guidelines.

The list created inside of the CLI is only able to keep track of one
session and the list is destroyed after the session ends.

This makes the app useless unless the user keeps it open all the
time and if the app is deleted, the user loses all access to what
he/she has done.

Lets create a Storage class to enable long term storage and give the
user the power to decide when to delete tasks even after closing the
session.

Long term storage makes the app more robust in case of accidental
closing of the CLI app and eventually the real app.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add load and modify delete functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The implementation of the long-term storage is incomplete due to
inability to load and delete properly from the long term storage
file.

This makes the app unable to access the information it has stored
and essentially be the same as before the long term storage.

Lets add load and delete from file functionality. Lets also add a
clear functionality to aid with the delete functionality.

The long term storage will now be completely accessible by the app
and be able to support memory between sessions.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Check if Storage Directory exists
commitResults.messageBody:
The program only checked if the file existed not the directory.

If the directory did not exist, the program would have thrown an
error on the first opening of the app itself.

Lets add a check to see if the directory exists when loading the app
at the start of every session.

This makes the system more robust on initial opening and even if the
directory was deleted by accident.

Minor fix to ensure runtest files working as intended after
implementing the check and create directory on top of file.

Deadlines and Event times are stored as string.

Program is unable to verify or use the time inputs from user in any
meaningful way.

Lets add time functionality to these two classes by using the
LocalDateTime package from java.

By storing times as LocalDateTime objects, these objects can be used
for more meaningful interactions with the user in future commands
such as looking up upcoming deadlines or events. This also serves as
a check for valid dates and times for events.

Time was merely stored and output in terms of LocalDateTime objects.

There is potential for more uses of said objects as per last commit.

Lets implement a more meaningful use of said data by printing all
upcoming deadlines and events only if they are unmarked.

With this, users will be able to check all upcoming tasks which they
have not done in the event that the list is very huge.

The files are not divided into proper packages.

This makes it difficult for any reader to understand which types are
related, where to find which type of classes. It also can cause
namespace conflicts if the number of classes were to increase and
does not encapsulate data well within certain types of files.

Lets separate the files into packages, with the main package being
mortal_reminder, and inside that package we will have 4 subpackages,
namely backend, commands, io and tasks. The main method will remain
inside of the main package as a standalone file.

With these changes, the backend, the tasks, command types and the
user interaction files will all be separated within their own
package folders and the programmer can easily find and change files
they need to in an intuitive manner.

The app needs to be built and tested manually right now.

Testing and building are two of the things which can be automated
in a project to lighten the load of a programmer as well as ensure
build consistency.

Lets add gradle support for the project.

With gradle support, right now, we can build the project automatically
and run it automatically.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add JUnit Test for TaskList getTask method
commitResults.messageBody:
We have been testing the entire application in entirety so far, and
not specific methods to ensure it is not buggy.

This makes it difficult to pinpoint sources of error in the code and
increases the overall debugging time.

Lets create JUnit tests to test the getTask method inside of
TaskList.java. This method is integral to the application because
it is a key part of data storing and manipulation. If this method is
buggy, it may be easy to notice in the results but time-consuming to
check.

Thus, lets create an automated method to test this method to save
debugging time in future.

We have been testing the entire application in entirety so far, and
not specific methods to ensure it is not buggy.

This makes it difficult to pinpoint sources of error in the code and
increases the overall debugging time.

Lets create JUnit tests to test the loadTaskListFromFile method
inside of Storage.java.

This method is integral to the application because it is ensures the
long-term memory of the app. If this method is buggy, it may not be
very obvious at first glance, unless tested further in depth.

Thus, an automated method to test this method was created to save
debugging time in future.
Completed gradle automation of building a JAR file with each build.

All methods were not explained adequately inside the code.

This can lead to future programmers being unable to understand how
to modify the existing code making the code difficult to be improved
on.

Lets add javadocs to as many methods and classed as possible
explaining their functionality succinctly.

This will allow other programmers reading the code to understand and
work with the code or even create tests for the code more easily.

commitResults.messageTitle: Formatted code to follow a consistent code style
commitResults.messageBody:
There is some inconsistency in the import lines and the code style
for some of the files.

This makes the code slightly unreadable to the user.

Lets reformat the code using the IDE automation and follow the
recommended coding style in the CS2103 coding style recommendations.

This will make the code alot more readable to the user.

The list of tasks an actual user will work with is usually rather
large.

This makes it sometimes difficult to find specific task that you have
added in before.

Lets add search functionality for users to be able to use to find
all tasks with similar description to what they have searched for.

This will make the app more easy for users to use in a real
application.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/mortal_reminder/backend/TaskList.java

Marking and Unmarking tasks are not captured in the storage.

If a user were to mark the task and close the app, the change would
not be captured inside of the storage file and would not be reflected
in the app the next time it is turned on.

Lets add the refreshStorage method to the mark and unmark methods to
ensure the changes are kept each time the app is closed.

That should fix any long term memory loss issues with the mark and
unmark methods.
Minor format changes before starting on new weeks work

Add checkstyle to the project to track objective style issues to
automatically be ironed out.

Some of the current java coding standard violations may not be
easily caught by the developer.

These coding violations may go unnoticed and cause inconsistency
down the line.

Let's integrate CheckStyle to automatically check and help the
developer to rectify any coding violations real time, saving a lot
of time down the line.

Command Line App is not appealing to many people who may not use the
app just because the user interface (command line is difficult to use)

The command line also makes it difficult to see history of the chat
with the bot because it does not provide a good text field for the user
to use.

Lets add a GUI using JavaFX to our app to allow better interaction
with the user. Build just the basic app (interaction with the user
only, no welcome message) first.

This will make the app more appealing to potential users and make
interaction much easier.

The GUI did not have a welcome message, so it seemed very abrupt
when the application started.

This may seem confusing to the reader when they use it for the first
time and be unable to understand what to do next.

Let's add some formatting and a welcome message to the app.

This allows the user to have some form of understanding of what the
app is about to do and have a more intuitive start to the application.

commitResults.messageTitle: Modify JavaFX version to match runtime version
commitResults.messageBody:
There is a mismatch between the javafx versions in the .xml files
and the build.gradle file.

This causes error messages to show up and may cause issues in
code behaviour down the road.

Lets modify both javafx versions to be '17.0.7'.

This will ensure consistency in javafx versions being used.

List Storage file is left as a standalone file inside of the
resources folder.

This is messy for code organisation and readability and reduces
any improvement potential by other developers in future.

Lets create a folder 'data' to keep the storage list file for better
organisation.

This will make the code more readable and intuitive for future
developers.

commitResults.messageTitle: Format code according to code style
commitResults.messageBody:
There is some error in the order of imports and missing spaces.

This makes the code unreadable to future developers.

Lets reformat the order of imports to make it look more readable.

This will make the code base more consistent and usable for future
developers.

Find is restricted to only one search phrase.

This makes it inflexible to search for things that may be related
but not with the same phrases. For example, read book and write
report are both within similar domains of study but do not share
similar phrases. As such, there needs to be a way to quick search
them.

Lets add Varargs to the find function, and allow different search
terms to be separated with a comma.

This allows similar types of things to be searched together.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add dynamic background colour for DialogBox
commitResults.messageBody:
The background colours for the DialogBox are pretty uninteresting as
they are all green with black text.

The user is unable to immediately tell if the command they sent was
indeed recorded correctly or not as there is no visual feedback.

Lets add dynamic colouring to the dialogbox so that there is visual
feedback on the type of command that was just processed by the user.

This will give the user a better user experience and ability to
instantly recognise if they had made an error in passing a command
previously just by the colour of the dialogbox.

Some methods' Javadocs were not updated after the GUI was added.

These methods changed from being void (due to the use of System.out.
println) but changed to returning a string which then is printed on
the GUI.

This makes the Javadoc outdated and difficult for future developers
to refer to.

Lets update the Javadocs to make the code more readable and
understandable.

This would then allow future developers to understand the use of the
modified methods with no confusion.

The exception handling is not consistent throughout the entire file.

This prevents specific debugging methods to each specific problems
and also makes the code more difficult to follow.

Let's add a new Exception class to handle all the exceptions in the
current iteration of the project.

This makes the code more readable and future exceptions easier
to add.

Not all exceptions have been reformatted with the new class.

This makes the previous commit incomplete.

Lets complete reformatting all the exceptions into the new exception class.

This will complete the exception handling thus far.

The code is not completely adherent to the code style and
conventions inside of the CS2103 requirements.

This makes the code seem like it is not consistently done by one
person.

Lets modify some parts of the code not adherent to the codestyle.

This will make the code more consistent and readable.

The current code does not completely adhere to the requirements of the course.

Lets format some of the code so that the coding standard violations are fixed and
the code looks more consistent.

This will make the code more readable and consistent to the coding standard of
the course.

There are some violations of the naming convention and javadocs.

This makes the code abit confusing to follow.

Let's reformat and cleanup both the javadocs and the method names to
make the code alot more readable for future users.

There is a method deleteTask() which holds an assumption that has
has not been explicitly shown in the code. Delete task will always
only be run once there are tasks that have been added to the
taskList in the first place and have already been checked for
validity in the addTask or loadTask method call.

By not showing this assumption to the future developers, they may
not be aware of this and try to change the method in an unintended
way, which may break the delete function.

Let's create an assertion at the else statement inside the
deleteTask method that ensures the code does not ever reach that
location.

This will help new developers understand the code better AND it
becomes more apparent when this assumption is no longer true,
prompting the developer to modify other methods like the addTask
and loadTask method such that the assumption becomes true again.

There is a fair bit of assumptions made inside the methods of
Processor.java, specifically in the markUnmarkOrDelete and
createTask methods.

In both methods, if-else statements were used to call on the last
conditional in the method but if the handleCommand method was to be
modified, there is no guarantee that this assumption will hold.

Let's add these assumptions to ensure that the developer knows about
the said assumptions and modifies other methods in the project
around these assumptions.

This will make the project less confusing to work on in the future.
Add assertions to Processor.java and TaskList.Java

Some code blocks are long and nested and some magic numbers were
used.

This affects readability of code.

Lets reduce the nested code inside of the Processor.java,
Storage.java and Parser.java. Lets add some comments
to explain the magic letters inside of Todo.java. Deadline.java
and Event.java.

This makes the code alot more understandable to future developers.

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/mortalreminder/backend/Processor.java

The current code quality is decent but there is room for improvement.

There are some complex methods and there is room to make the happy
path more apparent in the code.

Lets reduce the nesting in these complicated methods specifically
in the Processor.java to make the happy path more apparent.

This makes the code alot more readable and less confusing for future
developers.

There is a lot of accumulated technical debt as until now, the focus
was on getting the code to work properly.

This made some of the code be redundant and other parts of the code
to be very long.

Let's refactor the code and re-organise the methods and classes to
ensure that the code organisation and quality improves.

This will reduce the technical debt accumulated, making the codebase
more useable for the future.
Code Refactoring

commitResults.messageTitle: Add Streams to find task function
commitResults.messageBody:
The function has two nested for-loops.

This may affect code quality down the line.

Let's implement the method using streams to improve the readability
and clarity of the method to other developers.

This will make the code look a lot more clean.

This allows for continuous integration of the project inside of
github.

The commands are very rigid and not customisable.

This increases user frustration when they misspell a single word in
a long command.

Let's add functionality to make the commands more flexible and be
called on using different words.

This makes the user experience better and more customised to each
user.

The necessary storage files were not being created on first start of
the app.

The user will be confused at the error message and not want to use
the app anymore.

Let's improve the first startup experience and enable all necessary
file creations upon the first creation of the app.

This will make the initial user experience much better and smoother
for new users.

The javadoc is based on the old method before refactoring the code.

The doc explains the older format of the method when it dealt with
all of marking, unmarking and deletion. This is confusing for any
new developers of the project.

Let's update the Javadoc such that it reflects the new functions of
the method after refactoring.

This makes the method more understandable for new developers when
they need to modify the method or use the method for other methods
of the program.

**Note I was testing a use case to let AI write my commit messages
and this is the result from ChatGPT". I based it on other commit
messages I wrote in the past:

The handleUserInput method was refactored to improve clarity and
error handling when processing user input and executing commands.
The following changes were made:

- Reorganized the dialogContainer's getChildren().addAll() calls
  for better code readability and maintainability.
- Extracted common dialog box addition logic into a single block,
  reducing code duplication.
- Improved error handling by catching MortalReminderException and
  providing more specific feedback when an exception occurs.
- Enhanced the dialog creation by ensuring correct command type
  (known or unknown) is reflected in the mortal reminder dialog.

This update makes the code easier to maintain, reduces redundancy,
and provides clearer messaging for both successful and erroneous
cases.

The test is not setting up and cleaning the relevant files before
and after the test.

This leads to issues in passing the test especially if the storage
list file already contained some items in it.

Lets add "@BeforeEach" and "@AfterEach" command for this file to
set up proper testing environments before and after each test case
while also following the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle.

This allows the testing process to be smoother for further builds
and github continuous integrations.

This method is crucial in our program but is not robustly tested.

This may lead to many errors in coding not being correctly caught at
the bud when its dependent methods are modified without care about
the effect on this class.

Lets add more robust test cases for this method to quickly ensure
any regressions are caught timely and modified accordingly.

This should save a lot of time and effort as more modifications are
made for the program.

The AI-assistance documentation has not been updated in a while.

A lot of AI assistance was used for many methods and is difficult to
keep track of.

Lets update the AI.md to quickly document all the ways AI was used
and lessons learnt during the journey.

This will help close learning loop and give credit where its due
to prevent accusations of plagiarism.

There is a regression error that is spotted on Event.java due to
added space before the "/from" inside of the getDescription() method.

This causes one of the test cases to fail which prevents continuous
integration inside github.

Let's fix the regression error inside Event.java.

This will allow the build to be created successfully and CI to be
smooth.

The locale of the DateTimeFormat class was not specified.

When different OS or machines use the program, the program will
follow their specific device locale and this will cause problems for
the storage of the times.

Let's add a specific locale to follow for the program.

This will allow the behaviour of the DateTimeFormat class to be
consistent across many different devices and OS.
